title: 575-C
statement: C. Partytime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test4 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputNote the unusual memory limit for the problem.People working in MDCS (Microsoft Development Center Serbia) like partying. They usually go to night clubs on Friday and Saturday.There areNpeople working in MDCS and there areNclubs in the city. Unfortunately, if there is more than one Microsoft employee in night club, level of coolness goes infinitely high and party is over, so club owners will never let more than one Microsoft employee enter their club in the same week (just to be sure).You are organizing night life for Microsoft employees and you have statistics about how much every employee likes Friday and Saturday parties for all clubs.You need to match people with clubs maximizing overall sum of their happiness (they are happy as much as they like the club), whilehalfof people should go clubbing on Friday and the otherhalfon Saturday.InputThe first line contains integerN— number of employees in MDCS.Then anN×Nmatrix follows, where element ini-th row andj-th column is an integer number that represents how muchi-th person likesj-th club’sFridayparty.Then anotherN×Nmatrix follows, where element ini-th row andj-th column is an integer number that represents how muchi-th person likesj-th club’sSaturdayparty.2 ≤N≤ 20Nis even0 ≤level of likeness≤ 106All values are integersOutputOutput should contain a single integer — maximum sum of happiness possible.ExamplesInput41 2 3 42 3 4 13 4 1 24 1 2 35 8 7 16 9 81 355 78 1 61 1 1 1Output167NoteHere is how we matched people with clubs:Friday: 1st person with 4th club (4 happiness) and 4th person with 1st club (4 happiness).Saturday: 2nd person with 3rd club (81 happiness) and 3rd person with 2nd club (78 happiness).4+4+81+78 = 167

processed.result:
There are $N$ people and $N$ clubs. Each person has a happiness level for each club on Friday and Saturday.  

You need to assign each person to a club for either Friday or Saturday, such that:

*  Half the people go to clubs on Friday, and half on Saturday.
*  No club has more than one person.

The goal is to maximize the total happiness of all the people. 

**Input:**

* The first line contains the number of people, $N$.
* The next $N \times N$ matrix contains the happiness levels for each person at each club on Friday.
* The following $N \times N$ matrix contains the happiness levels for each person at each club on Saturday.

**Output:**

* A single integer representing the maximum total happiness achievable.

You have a group of people and a set of clubs. Each person has a happiness score for each club on Friday and Saturday.  You need to assign each person to a club for one day (Friday or Saturday) to maximize the total happiness, ensuring that half the people go to clubs on Friday and the other half on Saturday.  No two people can go to the same club on the same day.
